ENGLISH: In a major address before the National Press Club, the Secretary of State has outlined the regions vital to American security in the Pacific. The speech reaffirmed commitments to Japan, the Philippines, and the island chain stretching through the Western Pacific.\nAt the same time, it avoided explicit reference to the Korean Peninsula.\nWhile the intent was to clarify America’s strategic priorities, foreign observers may draw their own conclusions from what was left unsaid.

Observers around the world are analyzing a recent speech by the American Secretary of State outlining the United States’ defensive commitments in Asia.\nWhile Japan and the Philippines were explicitly named as falling within America’s security perimeter, the Korean Peninsula was conspicuously absent.\nWhether this omission reflects a deliberate shift in policy or mere diplomatic caution remains unclear. What is certain is that the balance of expectations in East Asia has changed.
